content.text: It all started back in 2020.

At that time, my Instagram username was @jvedant7. I liked it, and naturally, I wanted to use the same username across all other platforms. But there was a problem it was already taken almost everywhere.

So began the hunt for a new username.
I didn‚Äôt want something random or trendy. I wanted a name that actually meant something. To make things clearer, I set a few strict rules for myself:

items: No digits or special characters (I absolutely hate them)
It had to be available on all major platforms
And most importantly, it should contain all the letters of my name

content.text: With these criteria in mind, I went deep into the internet‚Äîsearching, experimenting, rearranging letters, and exploring meaningful names. After a lot of digging, I finally stumbled upon something interesting.
That‚Äôs when I found Vemacitrin.

content.html:
Wikipedia

Vemacitrin

Vemacitrin (Sanskrit), also known as Vepacitti (PƒÅli), is the name of a leader of the Asuras who figures prominently in many Buddhist s≈´tras.

Vemacitrin is the most prominent of the leaders of the Asuras in their fight with the devas of TrƒÅyastri·πÉ≈õa where they had formerly lived. After one battle he was made prisoner and bound before the throne of ≈öakra, ruler of TrƒÅyastri·πÉ≈õa, whom he treated with bitter verbal abuse. ≈öakra bore his insults patiently, and argued that such patience was a sign of strength, not of weakness.

content.text: The name felt unique, ancient, and strong‚Äîand the best part? It contained every letter of my name.

That moment, everything clicked.
The username was meaningful, clean, available across platforms, and deeply connected to my identity. And that‚Äôs how vemacitrind was born.
Sometimes, a username isn‚Äôt just a name‚Äîit‚Äôs a story.
Now, if you ever want to check whether I‚Äôm on a social media platform or not, just search for vemacitrind.

title: Unforgettable Sunday Afternoon at the Shop

content.text: I started helping my father in our shop when I was in the 3rd or 4th standard. What began as small tasks slowly turned into real responsibility. By 2021, when I was in 12th grade, I was just 17 years old‚Äîand running the shop entirely on my father‚Äôs behalf.

That Sunday afternoon seemed ordinary at first, but it turned into an experience I‚Äôll never forget.Three girls walked into the shop. They were wearing typical Indian dupattas wrapped around their faces, the way many girls do while riding two-wheelers. Without much conversation, they quickly picked a belt from the display. It was a cheap one‚Äî‚Çπ150.
I politely asked if they wanted an extra hole punched in the belt. They refused. I packed the belt in a bag, took a ‚Çπ2000 note from one of them, and returned ‚Çπ1850 in change.

That‚Äôs when things got strange.
The girl suddenly said, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs only one belt.‚Äù

For a moment, I was confused. Did they think they were getting two belts for ‚Çπ150? I calmly explained that one belt costs ‚Çπ150. Without arguing further, they refused to buy it. They handed back the belt and the change I had given them, and I returned the ‚Çπ2000 note.

Everything happened very fast‚Äîbut something didn‚Äôt feel right.
As soon as they turned to leave, I checked the cash. My heart sank. ‚Çπ600 was missing‚Äîthree ‚Çπ200 notes.
I was stunned üò∂.

Instinctively, I rushed from behind the counter and shouted in Gujarati,
‚ÄúAai jao, lai lo 150 ma 2!‚Äù
(‚ÄúCome back, take two belts for ‚Çπ150!‚Äù)

All three of them turned back.As the girl who had handed me the money came closer, I grabbed her hand and twisted it slightly‚Äîand there they were. The missing ‚Çπ200 notes clenched in her palm. I snatched the money back and yelled, asking why she had taken it.
They immediately started making excuses, claiming it was a mistake.

By then, my voice was loud enough to draw attention. Nearby shopkeepers came out to see what was happening. One of them advised me to let the girls go, saying that calling the police would only create more trouble‚Äîespecially since my father was out of town.
After they left, I stood there frozen. For nearly ten minutes, I could barely breathe.

That incident changed me.
Until that day, I believed running a shop was simple‚Äîsell, bill, smile, repeat. But I learned, far too early, that being a shopkeeper also means being alert, brave, and ready to face situations no textbook ever prepares you for.
This is Probably one of easiest CTF challenges on TryHackMe. But again, it's a good exercise for beginners practiceing their skills.
Just like always, I started with an Nmap scan to identify open ports and services running on the target machine.

‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄvemacitrind„âøvemacitrind-[~/Documents/TryHackMe/PickleRick]
‚îî‚îÄ$ nmap -sS -T4 -n 10.48.168.199

Starting Nmap 7.95 ( https://nmap.org ) at 2026-01-16 14:39 IST
Nmap scan report for 10.48.168.199
Host is up (0.094s latency).
Not shown: 998 closed tcp ports (reset)

PORT   STATE SERVICE
22/tcp open  ssh
80/tcp open  http

Nmap done: 1 IP address (1 host up) scanned in 2.50 seconds
I just ignored the ssh becuase as long as we don't have any credentials we can't do much with it. So I moved to port 80 which is hosting a web application.

I find it running Apache HTTP Server 2.4.41. So I thought for a easy challenge, there must be some known vulnerabilities. After a quick search for it but i found nothing useful. So I decided to enumerate the web application further using ffuf.
I found assests directory containing bunch of photos and .gif files. Nothing useful
While trying to find something interesting, I found Username in source code.

So I had Username but no password. While exploring further I visit robots.txt and found something like 'Wubbalubbadubdub'. As a Rick and Morty fan, I knew it's password. I tryed to login with these credentials on ssh but it didn't worked. So I try to find some place where I can use these credentials. I remembered assests directory. there were multiple images But none of them were use anywhere in the web there should be some place where these images are used. I try every imgname + .php and finally I found one.
I found an login page. After Logining with above credentials, I was in.
There was a command panel so I try ls and it worked. I found there were file 'Sup3rS3cretPickl3Ingred.txt' i try to read it using cat command and this happended.
It seems we have a little bit of a challenge here. I try diffrent cmd like head, tail, echo $(cat ...) and finally less worked. And we got 1 out 3 ingredients aka flag.
less Sup3rS3cretPickl3Ingred.txt
I keep messing around with command panel and I run 'sudo -l' and found that www-data can run ALL as root without password.

Matching Defaults entries for www-data on ip-10-48-168-199:
        env_reset, mail_badpass, secure_path=/usr/local/sbin\:/usr/local/bin\:/usr/sbin\:/usr/bin\:/sbin\:/bin, use_pty
User www-data may run the following commands on ip-10-48-168-199:
    (ALL) NOPASSWD: ALL
Then it become child play. I just run sudo less /home/rick/flag.txt and sudo less /root/flag.txt to get both user and root flag.
